layer.name: Sacrifice
layer.definition: Pour out for others with no expectation of return.

questions.text: Using my credibility to advocate for people who have none is ...
questions.principle: Reputation can be spent for others

answers.4: common — I spend moral capital for others
answers.5: expected — that's what reputation is for
answers.3: moderate — when the cost is manageable

questions.text: Defending unpopular positions or people at cost to my standing is ...

answers.4: common — truth matters more than popularity
answers.5: automatic — I defend what's right regardless of cost
answers.2: occasional — when I feel strongly enough

questions.text: Speaking uncomfortable truth when it would be easier to stay silent is ...

answers.4: common — I say what needs saying
answers.2: occasional — when the stakes are high
answers.1: rare — I prefer to keep the peace

questions.text: Moral stands that cost me relationships or opportunities (without regret) is ...

answers.4: real — I've paid prices and accepted it
answers.5: part of the cost — integrity is worth any price
answers.1: not my experience — I avoid those situations

questions.text: Advocating for the voiceless with nothing in it for me is ...
questions.principle: Advocacy for the powerless is pure sacrifice

answers.4: regular — I actively seek to advocate
answers.5: central — the voiceless are my priority
answers.1: rare — I focus on my own concerns

remediation.advice: Moral capital can be hoarded or spent. Hoarding means protecting your reputation, avoiding controversy, staying safe. Spending means using the credibility you've built to advocate for truth, defend the weak, and challenge injustice — even at cost to yourself.

scripture.text: Open your mouth for the mute, for the rights of all who are destitute.
